text: - Are you looking to start a career
developing software that runs on AWS?
Or are you trying to understand more
about how developing applications with AWS
benefits developers?

Join us for the Building
Serverless Applications
on AWS series.
If you are currently working on software

or want to get up to
speed on AWS services,
this is the right series for you.

This series follows an
application's journey,

starting with it running
on a local machine

and then refactoring the app
to use cloud native services.

We'll use a bit of imagination
as the series progresses.
You will put yourself in the shoes

of a newly hired consultant
software engineer
moving from project to project.

Your employer specializes in
applications hosted on AWS
and specifically serverless architectures.
As you move to each new engagement,
you have a little bit of learning to do

like what services your
new customer is using

and what problems are gonna
be solved with each service.

This series has three
courses that progress you

through your first few weeks
at the software consultancy,

and every course focuses on
serverless architectures.

The first course is called
Integrating AWS with the SDKs.

In this course, we start with
a very simple application
that we've decided needs to move to AWS,

and you're the consultant that's
going to make that happen.

This course kicks off
with the basics of AWS,
first answering the question

what does AWS mean to you
as a software engineer,

including answering
questions around what AWS is
and the benefits of AWS to a developer.

We then move onto securing
access to your AWS environment

using the service AWS Identity
and Access Management.

We cover concepts like
users, groups, roles,
and how to create and manage access keys.

The application you will
be building needs storage,
and we'll cover how to use Amazon S3

within an application reading
and writing objects to S3.

Our application will also need
to store data in a database,
and this course covers the basics

on how to use Amazon
DynamoDB, a NoSQL database.
We will also need to use a compute service
to host the application,

and we'll be using AWS Lambda,
a serverless compute service.
You'll learn the basics around AWS Lambda

and get hands-on experience
building out the functions,

also seeing multiple
examples of Lambda functions
throughout the course.

You'll also learn how to
expose Lambda functions as APIs
using Amazon API Gateway.
That's the first course in the series.

The second course is called
Serverless Architectures on AWS.
This course will move you further

into your role as a
developer at the consultancy,
and you'll begin to use automation tools.
The consultancy wants you to work
in an infrastructure-as-code model
where you create declarative templates
to define resources in AWS.

Some of the tools used to
build out applications on AWS
will include AWS CloudFormation,

AWS Serverless Application
Model, and AWS Amplify.

At this point in the
series, your applications

will need to add
authentication to the APIs
so they are secure.

We'll be using Amazon Cognito
to complete this task.
Your next task will be to learn
about using event-driven architectures.

And to do that, you'll need
to know about AWS services
like Amazon Simple Queue Service,

Amazon Simple Notification
Service, and Amazon EventBridge.

You'll also learn the basics
around how to create workflows
using AWS Step Functions,
and you'll see a few different examples

of event-driven architectures
in this section of the course.

Then it will be time for the
third course in the series:

Hands-on with AWS Software
Development Practices.

This course is all about
getting you talking
like a software engineer.
You will get familiar

with how your team works and
pushes code into production.

A lot of working with
technology is knowing the lingo,
and we want to help shed some light
on the vocabulary around DevOps.

We also want to provide
you with information
on working like a software engineer
using source control, writing unit test,
and using automated deployment pipelines,
all important tasks for software engineer.
You'll learn about continuous integration
and continuous delivery or CI/CD.
In this course, you will get hands-on

with a pipeline created using
services like AWS CodeCommit,

AWS CodeBuild, AWS CodeDeploy,
and AWS CodePipeline.

At the end of the series,
you'll be more prepared

for a modern software development
job using AWS services,
common industry practices,
and building cloud native applications.
Join us for this three-course series,

and kickstart your career
with development in AWS.
We hope to see you soon.
(gentle music)
